question_text.markdown:
Given below are two statements:

**Statement I:** Along the period, the chemical reactivity of the element gradually increases from group 1 to group 18.

**Statement II:** The nature of oxides formed by group 1 element is basic while that of group 17 elements is acidic.

(JEE Main, 30 Jan 2024)

options.text: Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
Statement I is true but Statement II is False.
Statement I is false but Statement II is true.
Both Statement I and Statement II are false.

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3)**

St. I is FALSE: Reactivity does NOT gradually increase from Group 1 to 18. Noble gases (Group 18) are least reactive.

St. II is TRUE: Group 1 oxides (Na2O, K2O) are basic. Group 17 oxides (Cl2O7) are acidic.

question_text.markdown:
In case of isoelectronic species the size of F$^-$, Ne and Na$^+$ is affected by:

(JEE Main, 01 Feb 2024)

options.text: None of the factors because their size is the same
Electron-electron interaction in the outer orbitals

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) Nuclear charge (Z)**

F-, Ne, Na+ all have 10 electrons. Same n, same electron count. Only Z differs: F-(Z=9) > Ne(Z=10) > Na+(Z=11) in size. Higher Z = stronger pull = smaller size.

question_text.markdown:
Lowest oxidation number of an atom in a compound A$_2$B is $-2$. The number of electrons in its valence shell is ____.

(JEE Main, 01 Feb 2024)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: 6**

In A2B, B has OS = -2. Minimum OS = -2 means Group 16 element (O, S, Se, Te). Group 16 valence shell = ns2 np4 = 6 valence electrons.

question_text.markdown:
Given below are two statements:

**Assertion A:** The energy required to form Mg$^{2+}$ from Mg is much higher than that required to produce Mg$^+$.

**Reason R:** Mg$^{2+}$ is small ion and carries more charge than Mg$^+$.

(JEE Main, 10 Apr 2023)

options.text: Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
A is false but R is true
Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4)**

IE1(Mg)=738, IE2(Mg)=1451 kJ/mol. Total for Mg2+ >> Mg+. Mg2+ is smaller and more charged, so second electron is removed from a +1 cation with smaller radius, requiring much more energy. R correctly explains A.

question_text.markdown:
For elements B, C, N, Li, Be, O and F, the correct order of first ionisation enthalpy is:

(JEE Main, 11 Apr 2023)

options.text: Li < Be < B < C < O < N < F
B < Li < Be < C < N < O < F
Li < Be < B < C < N < O < F
Li < B < Be < C < O < N < F

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) Li < B < Be < C < O < N < F**

IE1 (kJ/mol): Li(520) < B(800) < Be(899) < C(1086) < O(1314) < N(1402) < F(1681). Two anomalies: Be > B (Be has stable filled 2s2); N > O (N has half-filled 2p3, O has paired 2p4 causing repulsion).

question_text.markdown:
Which of the following statements are **not** correct?

A. The electron gain enthalpy of F is more negative than that of Cl.
B. Ionization enthalpy decreases in a group of periodic table.
C. The electronegativity of an atom depends upon the atoms bonded to it.
D. Al$_2$O$_3$ and NO are examples of amphoteric oxides.

(JEE Main, 13 Apr 2023)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) A, C and D are NOT correct**

A wrong: Cl(-349) has more negative EGE than F(-328 kJ/mol). B correct: IE decreases down a group. C wrong: Electronegativity is an intrinsic property, not dependent on bonded atoms. D wrong: NO is a neutral oxide, not amphoteric.

question_text.markdown:
The correct increasing order of the ionic radii is:

(JEE Main, 31 Jan 2023)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) Ca2+ < K+ < Cl- < S2-**

All isoelectronic (18 electrons). Size increases as Z decreases: Ca2+(Z=20) < K+(Z=19) < Cl-(Z=17) < S2-(Z=16). S2- has lowest Z so it is largest.

question_text.markdown:
The correct order of ionic size of N$^{3-}$, Na$^+$, F$^-$, Mg$^{2+}$ and O$^{2-}$ is:

(JEE Main, 27 Jun 2022)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (1) Mg2+ < Na+ < F- < O2- < N3-**

All isoelectronic with 10 electrons. Size increases as Z decreases: Mg2+(Z=12) < Na+(Z=11) < F-(Z=9) < O2-(Z=8) < N3-(Z=7).

question_text.markdown:
The correct order of ionic radii for the ions P$^{3-}$, S$^{2-}$, Ca$^{2+}$, K$^+$, Cl$^-$ is:

(JEE Main, 27 Aug 2021)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (1) P3- > S2- > Cl- > K+ > Ca2+**

P3-, S2-, Cl- are isoelectronic (18e): P3-(Z=15) > S2-(Z=16) > Cl-(Z=17). K+, Ca2+ are also isoelectronic (18e): K+(Z=19) > Ca2+(Z=20). Anions are larger than cations for same electron count. So: P3- > S2- > Cl- > K+ > Ca2+.

question_text.markdown:
The ionic radii of K$^+$, Na$^+$, Al$^{3+}$ and Mg$^{2+}$ are in the order:

(JEE Main, 25 Jul 2021)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) Al3+ < Mg2+ < Na+ < K+**

Ionic radii (pm): Al3+(53) < Mg2+(72) < Na+(102) < K+(138). Down the group size increases (Na+ < K+). Higher charge on same period = smaller size (Al3+ < Mg2+ < Na+).

question_text.markdown:
The ionic radii of F$^-$ and O$^{2-}$ respectively are 1.33 A and 1.4 A, while the covalent radius of N is 0.74 A. The correct statement for the ionic radius of N$^{3-}$ is:

(JEE Main, 25 Jul 2021)

options.text: It is smaller than F- and N
It is bigger than O2- and F-
It is bigger than F- and N, but smaller than O2-
It is smaller than O2- and F-, but bigger than N

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) N3- is bigger than O2- and F-**

N3-, O2-, F- are isoelectronic (10 electrons). Size increases as Z decreases: F-(Z=9) < O2-(Z=8) < N3-(Z=7). So N3- is the largest. N3- > O2-(1.4 A) > F-(1.33 A).

question_text.markdown:
Match List-I with List-II:

(a) NaOH, (b) Be(OH)2, (c) Ca(OH)2, (d) B(OH)3, (e) Al(OH)3

(i) Acidic, (ii) Basic, (iii) Amphoteric

(JEE Main, 27 Jul 2021)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2)**

NaOH: strong base (ii). Be(OH)2: amphoteric (iii). Ca(OH)2: basic (ii). B(OH)3 = boric acid: acidic (i). Al(OH)3: amphoteric (iii).

question_text.markdown:
The characteristics of elements X, Y and Z with atomic numbers, respectively, 33, 53 and 83 are:

(JEE Main, 16 Mar 2021)

options.text: X and Y are metalloids and Z is a metal
X is a metalloid, Y is a non-metal and Z is a metal.
X, Y and Z are metals.
X and Z are non-metals and Y is a metalloid

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2)**

Z=33: As (Arsenic) - metalloid. Z=53: I (Iodine) - non-metal (halogen). Z=83: Bi (Bismuth) - metal (post-transition metal, Group 15).

question_text.markdown:
Which pair of oxides is acidic in nature?

(JEE Main, 26 Feb 2021)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) B2O3 and SiO2**

B2O3: acidic oxide (reacts with NaOH to form borax). SiO2: acidic oxide (reacts with NaOH to form Na2SiO3). CaO and BaO are basic oxides. N2O is a neutral oxide.

question_text.markdown:
The ionic radii of O$^{2-}$, F$^-$, Na$^+$ and Mg$^{2+}$ are in the order:

(JEE Main, 04 Sep 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) O2- > F- > Na+ > Mg2+**

All isoelectronic (10 electrons). Size decreases as Z increases: O2-(Z=8) > F-(Z=9) > Na+(Z=11) > Mg2+(Z=12).

question_text.markdown:
The correct order of the ionic radii of O$^{2-}$, N$^{3-}$, F$^-$, Mg$^{2+}$, Na$^+$ and Al$^{3+}$ is:

(JEE Main, 05 Sep 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) Al3+ < Mg2+ < Na+ < F- < O2- < N3-**

All isoelectronic (10 electrons). Size increases as Z decreases: Al3+(Z=13) < Mg2+(Z=12) < Na+(Z=11) < F-(Z=9) < O2-(Z=8) < N3-(Z=7).

question_text.markdown:
The acidic, basic and amphoteric oxides, respectively, are:

(JEE Main, 09 Jan 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) N2O3 (acidic), Li2O (basic), Al2O3 (amphoteric)**

N2O3: non-metal oxide = acidic. Li2O: alkali metal oxide = basic. Al2O3: reacts with both acids and bases = amphoteric.

question_text.markdown:
The IUPAC nomenclature of an element with electronic configuration [Rn] 5f$^{14}$ 6d$^1$ 7s$^2$ is:

(JEE Main, 25 Jul 2022)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) Unniltrium**

[Rn] 5f14 6d1 7s2: after Rn (Z=86), add 14 f-electrons (Z=100) + 1 d-electron = Z=103 (Lawrencium). IUPAC: un=1, nil=0, tri=3 -> Unniltrium (Unt). Z=103.

question_text.markdown:
The metal that has very low melting point and its periodic position is closer to a metalloid is:

(JEE Main, 26 Jul 2022)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) Ga (Gallium)**

Gallium has an anomalously low melting point (~29.76 C, just above room temperature). It is in Period 4, Group 13, adjacent to Ge (a metalloid) in the periodic table. Se is a non-metal, not a metal.

question_text.markdown:
Which of the following is a metalloid?

(JEE Main, 26 Jun 2022)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) Te (Tellurium)**

Metalloids: B, Si, Ge, As, Sb, Te, Po. Te (Z=52) is a recognized metalloid. Sc is a transition metal, Pb and Bi are post-transition metals.
